title: Physics Concepts as Indicative Framework to Ex-ante Modelling Systems of Economies
text:
Working Paper Draft  11 December 2025





1. Abstract
An explorative attempt …




2. Introduction
Nature strives through Physics to behave economical by using its resources in an austere way: Principle of Least Action.
Economy - not pre-given by natural laws - is constructed as social set of co-living rules to allocate, distribute and share (natural and non-natural) resources. Ex-ante modelling economic systems by rules (contractual, legislative, judicative, executive).
The state (situation, position) of the Economy can be described by e.g. Assets, Liabilities, Expenses, Incomes, Profitability, Productivity, etc.. The Economy changes through time from a state \(r_0=\) “start” to a state \(r_1=\) “end”. For the state to change, work is applied by processing limited resources (e.g. access to raw materials and availability of intermediate goods), constrained capital (e.g. financial funds, interest rates, and inflation), as well as labor capacity (e.g machines and human force).
How can a trajectory \(r = r_1 - r_0\) between two states be modelled by work \(W\), which is applied for the change of the state to occure: \(r = \int A = \int \int W\) ?





3. Work and Energy
\(\exists\) Work done or received \(W \neq 0 \Rrightarrow \exists\) Change of State (“Displacement”, “Deformation”) \(r \neq 0\):
\[\begin{split} &
W = \partial A = \partial(E \cdot t) = \partial(p ⋅ r)
\end{split} \tag{1}\]
Geometrical: \[\begin{split} &
W = F \cdot r = mr \cdot a = I ⋅ \frac{v}{t} =  \frac{p}{t} ⋅ tv = Ft \cdot v =  pv = mv^2
\end{split} \tag{2}\]
Analytical: \[\begin{split} &
W = \mathcal{L} + \mathcal{H} = (\mathcal{K} - \mathcal{U}) + (\mathcal{K} + \mathcal{U}) = (\mathcal{K} - (\mathcal{V} + \mathcal{Z})) + (\mathcal{K} + \mathcal{U}) = (\mathcal{K} - \mathcal{U}) + E
\end{split} \tag{3}\]
Electro Magnetic: \[\begin{split} &
W =  \left( \frac{1}{2}mv^2 - q(\Phi - \vec{\mathcal{A}} \cdot \vec{v}) \right) + \left( \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{m} (\vec{p} - q\vec{\mathcal{A}})^2 + q\Phi \right)\end{split} \tag{4}\]
Relativistic: \[\begin{split} &
W = \frac{v}{c} \sqrt{E^2 - (mc^2)^2}
\end{split} \tag{5}\]
Thermal: \[\begin{split} &
W = PV^{\iota} = T \cdot V^{\frac{f+2}{f}} = T \cdot V^{(\frac{c_P}{c_V}-1)} = T \cdot V^{\kappa-1} = T \cdot l \cdot g_0 = T \cdot n \cdot b_0 = T \cdot m \cdot c_0
\end{split} \tag{6}\]
Thermo Statistical: \[\begin{split} &
W = ΔY - ΔH = \Delta(T \cdot \Delta S - P \cdot \Delta V) - \Delta(T\cdot S)
\end{split} \tag{7}\]
Quantistic: \[\begin{split} &
W = ħ\mathcal{k} \cdot ω = ℎν\mathcal{k} = E\mathcal{k}
\end{split} \tag{8}\]

4. Productiviy and Utility
MACRO ECONOMY: GDP, Inflation, Import & Export, International Trade, Foreign Exchange, Money Quantity, Unemployment,
Goods Market (Production, Lager), Capital Market (Savings, Investments), Labor Market (Employment, Population Structure), Price vs. Value, Demand vs. Supply, Access to Resources, Trade & International Contracts
Assumin no waste.
Supply:
\[\begin{split} &
E = C + S + T + M - X
\end{split} \tag{9}\]
\[\begin{split} &
E = W  + E_P + E_B + T_B + E_G - Z_G
\end{split} \tag{10}\]
Demand:
\[\begin{split} &
V_I = C + I + G + X - M
\end{split} \tag{11}\]

\[\begin{split} &
E = V_I       \\&
W - C = S = I        \\&
C + S = W        \\&
C + I = R
\end{split} \tag{12}\]
Domestic Production & International Trade:
\[\begin{split} &

\end{split} \tag{13}\]

\end{split} \tag{15}\]

\end{split} \tag{16}\]

\[\begin{split} &
P \cdot V_I = U \cdot Q
\end{split} \tag{17}\]

5.Hypothesis and Conjecture
Conjecture of Equation 17 and Equation 6
How consistently map economical measures to the quantities of nature to model the economical system?
Input:
\[\begin{split} &
Input = f(Resouces, Labor, Capital) \text{ = Work = } \Delta Energy
\end{split} \tag{19}\]
Output:
\[\begin{split} &
Output = V_I \text{ = Goods + Services = Production = } \Delta State
\end{split} \tag{20}\]
Productivity:
\[\begin{split} &
Productivity = \frac{Output}{Input} = \frac{\Delta State}{\Delta Energy} = \frac{Production}{Work} = \frac{V_I}{F \cdot r}
\end{split} \tag{21}\]

\(\rightarrow\)

\(\leftarrow\)

As a first approach, let’s take the geometrical perspective of the concept of “work” (Equation 2), applied to basic economical measurements, so to satisfy the following system:
\(f_A(Assets) = f_L(Liabilities)\) = “momentum” \(p\) from initial state \(r_0\) to new state \(r_1\), and “state change” = \(r = r_1 - r_0\)
Assets = Property Capital (substance of matter, object movement/change) = \(m \cdot v\)
Liabilities = Financial Capital (space of movement, maneuverability) = \(m \cdot \frac{r}{t}\)
Expenses = \(m \cdot \frac{v}{t} \cdot r\) = \(\dot p \cdot r = F \cdot r\) = “work”
Income = \(\Delta E = \frac{1}{2} m v^2 + mv_0r\) = “energy change” = profit or loss

Thus, find \(r\) = “state change through trajectory” (Balance substance change) by given \(v\) = “velocity of movement” (Business speed), or find \(v\) by given \(r\); where \(r\), \(v\), and \(v_0\) shall be modeled within the constraints of contractual agreement means and by the given juristic legislation.
The constraints shall be modelled by the Lagrangian. Hence, “Work” shall be derived from the Hamiltonian which leads to the identification of the “movement” (= change, transformation) of the trajectory (= path to new state) with \(r\) and \(\dot p\).
